Problem:
Consider the linear transformation \( T: \mathbb{C}^n \rightarrow \mathbb{C}^n \) represented by matrix \( M \), and its impact on a complex function \( z(t) \) defined by \( z(t) = e^{i \omega t}v \), where \( v \) is a constant vector in \( \mathbb{C}^n \) and \( \omega \) a real number. We explore how the application of Laplace transform \( \mathcal{L} \{z(t)\} \) and its subsequent inverse alter the original function.

If \( T \) is applied to vector \( v \) at t = 0, transforming it to \( Mv \), and \( z(t) \) is computed without further intervention, will the resulting function at any t > 0 be the same when the transformation does not apply?
Explanation: The application of \( T \) alters the vector \( v \) to \( Mv \) resulting in a new function \( z(t) = e^{i \omega t}Mv \). This is not equal to the original \( e^{i \omega t}v \) unless \( M \) is a scalar matrix proportional to the identity, therefore influencing how the function evolves over time.
